our mission is to solve the most important and fundamental challenges in robotics and AI we're really focused on
longer term problems and making a more um lasting impact in the field and in
terms of the machine learning portion we're focused on two big areas one is
what we call athletic intelligence and that means giving robots dexterity um
giving them the ability to manipulate things and navigate rooms and different
environments and also cognitive intelligence so helping robots really understand the world they live in this
is through work that includes Foundation models task and motion planning and
Associated projects like how do we collect bigger and better um data data so at the AI Institute we have a

projects so I wanted to first start off uh and motivate the talk by kind of
showing one end result of uh our platform so here you can see there's a
policy deployed on a Boston Dynamic spot robot you can initialize so you can have
the spot start in many different start positions but it's able to detect where this bike seat is and extract it from
the Shelf um so what is the machine learning model behind this kind of
work this is something called uh robotics imitation learning and
imitation learning is learning from demonstration so one kind of imitation
learning is called Behavior cloning where you learn a policy directly from the input and output data with
supervised learning I'm sure all of you have heard of llms they're actually one really famous example of behavior
cloning of course with other reinforcement learning that happens afterwards if you think about llms it's
actually a sequential decision-making problem so every token prediction affects the next token prediction and in
robotics imitation learn learning instead of predicting tokens we're predicting actions and similarly one
action prediction affects the next action prediction robotic citation learning is
actually a very very difficult problem if you think about how it Compares with llms uh one way to think about it is
what's the difference between predicting actions and predicting language tokens well actions are actually in this
continuous space well language tokens are discreet also when you have a robot
operating in the real world there's just a lot of stochasticity from the environment there's a lot of Randomness
and you don't get this type of Randomness in llms so it's actually a much more difficult
problem in the last um slide I showed the video of the spot robot and that's
actually one example of a Visio motor policy which essentially means control from Pixel so uh the spot has a camera
on it and it it's taking images of what it and this image is fed into an encoder
the encoder produces an embedding vector and along with the state Vector of the robot this is input into a policy and
that policy outputs an action um one kind of more tangible
example of this is an autonomous driving so the cars can have cameras and they'll see the road you pass it through a
machine learning model and the model tells you to steer right or left so it's very similar to
that to do this type of machine learning the full life cycle includes data
collection data processing data training uh machine uh distributed training and deployment on the robot there are some
very unique challenges associated with robotics uh one is to do the training
you want data and data collection in robotics is slow and expensive um so
there's a lot of work in this area but even some of the most recent work maybe gives you on the order of 100
demonstrations in hour so it's very very expensive um these robots Al also operate in these Dynamic multi-actor
environments so you really want enough data to be able to compensate for that
some people solve this problem by using simulated data and that's a very good approach but there is this Sim toore Gap
so uh it's not so simple as just Sim um generating ton of simulated data and
then being able to transfer that to the real world there's still that Gap there that is being worked on in this field
and lastly we actually need to deploy these models on real robots and so there are a bunch of resource constraints
associated with that um which is another challenge in robotics today we wanted to focus kind
of on like uh the middle section of this life cycle so in the data processing and the distributed training uh which Rey
helps us a lot with and I lastly I also wanted to
mention our specific ml training challenges at The Institute so one is we're a research institute we have a
bunch of different projects we have many users using the same platform that we're building so we want to make sure we have
Fair resource allocation but no resource contention between the different uh jobs
that are happening at once we do have a shared uh gke cluster that we're using
and so how to design that system was something we thought a lot about and then also on the data side um our data
is growing um it doesn't necessarily fit in memory so how do we do that processing
effectively um and at a research institute the data is continually changing the schema is changing so how
do you keep track of the different versioning um and lineage on the training side as I mentioned we have a
bunch of different approaches a bunch of different models so we're trying to support a really wide range of projects
and we want people to have reproducible results and lastly thing we'll go into
more in this talk is in robotics you can't do the normal train test split for
validation that you can do normally in machine learning uh so we actually wanted to integrate in our system this
simulation evaluation and that means being able to see how your current model
is doing in a simulated environment and whether the robot can successfully perform the task or not and we'll show a
little bit more of that later uh so to do to do this we actually built a new ml platform we call robot
tensors and this is a python API and it kind of brings together many different components so the compute infrastructure
the data the training the evaluation and the deployment and you can see here you can bring in data from our data platform
uh where people are contributing to at The Institute you can do this last mile data processing either online or offline
and pass it to the train module in the train module you can bring in your custom models your custom
configurations it's automatically integrated with weights and biases and you can also construct models that are
built off of other models so you can kind of piece together different models that other users have
contributed we built this um model evaluation with simulation that we'll go
into more later and we also provide some debugging tools to help people figure out what's going on and so these train
and tune uh jobs are submitted to our kubernetes cluster and that's integrated
with uh the weights and model A weights and bis model registry and we're planning to integrate that with the
inference side to then directly deploy that to the robot so we chose Ray because it's nice to have one framework
that kind of spans all these different things we're trying to do we use a lot
of many modules in Ray we use Ray data Ray core Ray train Ray tune also Ray
offers a lot of flexibility and I mentioned like we are supporting many different types of research projects so
uh it allowed us to build something that is very flexible and many different
people can use it so I wanted to go into kind of two different design uh choices we made for
this platform the first one I think if you all have been using Ray you know it's
not recommended to do multi-tenant ray clusters and as I mentioned before we
have a bunch of different users and we have the share infrastructure so how do we actually manage that so that all
these users can use this shared infrastructure and the way we did that is kind of by dividing um into these Dev
clusters and a production queue so Dev cluster is something where any user can
launch their own Ray cluster that Ray cluster is theirs it is always
available um but the trade off is it's a smaller cluster there aren't you won't
get as uh many of gpus but it's really meant for you to iterate really quickly
on so we want people to be able to do their model development their debugging and smaller scale training and uh
validation once they're ready they can then send these jobs over to the production queue and now they can
request the expensive gpus they can really scale up their training job but on this side um we're launching a
transient Ray cluster so the ray cluster spins up it runs into job and once it's done it can terminate um and so that's
how we manage to be able to solve this multi-tenant uh problem and still
support many many users and the other part I wanted to highlight is uh the simulation
evaluation so as I mentioned before uh this is really unique to robotics where
we want to have physical simulation in the loop and we wanted to be able to
autoscale this part independently from the training because the simulation evaluation it can happen on cheaper gpus
even CPUs we don't need to do it on the expensive training notes we wanted to
isolate the resources and the processes from the training so the training is not affected by this and we wanted to not
block the training so if someone decides to do training versus training and the simulation evaluation we want the
training side to be the same so this is where we felt Ray really
shrine for us we were able to basically have uh different resource types so we
have these data nodes that are doing the data pre-processing we have the train nodes doing the training part and then
we have uh Sim nodes doing the simulation evaluation and during training after every and EPO we actually
have this cobc system where the mod the current model is sent over to the simulation nodes and then we have the
simulation actor manager that's starts launching all these simulation evaluation jobs and once it's done the
results are all sent back to weights and biases so you can see them side by side you can see your train loss and then you
can see hey did the robot actually complete the task in the simulation um this was very powerful and
on top of that Ray also allows you to have different environments uh for different actors and
so we were able to you know run uh different types of simulation environments that have
conflicting uh dependencies which is very very important uh we actually spent
quite a bit of time on this actor manager part because we actually run thousands of simulations per training
run and it's really easy to run into out of memory problems um and how to schedule it so
that you're getting the results back in a meaningful way um was something we spend a lot of effort
